author: jfresco

description.text:
The original design using binder clips served me well. But after a few iterations of that, I decided to make something a bit more fumble-free.

The spring is 1/4" x 1/2" x .035". Found bags of 5 at my local hardware store. I also use them for hotbed leveling. Screws are M3x5 flathead x 3 for mounting the motor. An M3x25 screw secures the arm through to the motor. A pair of M3x10 button head screws secure the top of the lever. The bowden tube is secured by threading a 4mm nut which is held in the lever by the top cap.

The bearing is a 608ZZ v-groove bearing. It seems to do a good job of keeping the filament on track. The guide and bowden tube are dead center to the bearing so that by itself helps too.

Remix of the remixed Saintflint Extruder by sonnylowe:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1265898

Original Saintflint design by mmemetea http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:987520

Easy to remove parts to service the extruder when needed.

I used the following parts:

  • a standard MK8 drive gear (ID 5mm, OD 8mm)
  • 624 bearings
  • M4 nuts on the Bowden tubes to lock them in place.
  • the spring I used comes from some clothing pegs:

Check the remix from sonnylowe for the parts I did not change and post.

print_settings.Notes:: Print it as a single perimeter wall 0.5mm-1mm(vase mode) with no top or bottom infill. Flip it if you have problems with bed adhesion.

description.text:
The fifth thing in my Week of Things, some useful, some just for fun. Thought this would force me to post some of my projects. Most are semi useful/functional and some are purely inspirational.

After getting a espresso machine I made this adaptor for the Mill attachment for Kitchenaid mixers. My idea was to grind the coffee beans straight down to the portafilter. It worked quite well but the grinds from flat burrs was not that good for espresso. Since then i've kept the adaptor on just so the things I mill don't go flying everywhere.

After printing it just slide it on the mill and enjoy.

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Print it as a single perimeter wall 0.5mm-1mm(vase mode) with no top or bottom infill. Flip it if you have problems with bed adhesion.

title: Stand for 6" Hasbro Black Series Star Wars Figures

description.text:
I've had a fair amount of trouble trying to display my 6" Black Series Star Wars figures on shelves, since many of them aren't very stable. You can buy stands on eBay, but they tend to cost around $5 apiece, which is quite expensive if you have a large collection. So I decided to make some of my own.

Hasbro has used at least two different sizes of foot holes for its figures, so I have provided two versions of the stand. Each is marked on the bottom so you can tell them apart. Version A is the one you'll want to use for most figures, while Version B has slightly larger pegs for figures like Vader and Chewbacca (and possibly others). I haven't been able to test these with every figure, so I can't guarantee these will work with everything, but please let me know if you do try them. The pegs are fairly tight, but that's the way you want it. Just sort of screw the feet on and most figures will stay on the stand quite well. I found that a silver or grey plastic looked the best. Black makes it too hard to see the logo.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/N5J582JLDn8" ></iframe>

description.text:
How many times , I needed to enlight an object from different angles and didn't find adequate support to hold flashlight torchs.

Edit: 20/08/2016 Added the "one-piece" BaseLeg versions. (cf comments)

<strong><font color="Orange" size="4">Overview & Background:</font></strong>



Let's describe why I started this project.

I have many LED torch lamp, different sizes and shapes.
I would torch lamp holders , which are the universal as possible, and adjustable in elevation, ie up and down .
Ok, maybe universal is too much for what I did, let's say it's suitable for the torchs that I have.

I wanted something, easy and fast to print.
Strong enough to be handled constantly.

Easy you said?

Hum...


In fact, I had to make several versions before I feel satisfied.

Anisotropy

The first think, when I have in mind the final shape idea, is,
how will I print it in order to have the optimized orientation in the X/Y printer axes.

Always thinking about the anisotropy effect.
Like someone working with wood needs to follow the fiber direction,
you need to care a lot about that.

In my opinion, most of time, the In-One-time-Printed-Piece is not a good solution
for many reasons:

  • The object will not be optimized for all axes constraints.
  • The object will need more Z axis access (means longer printing time)
  • The object will certainly need structure support material to fix the overhanging.




That's why this print process preparation is very important.
Instead of build the base and leg in one piece
I designed the base and leg in two pieces,
to have the base layers oriented horizontally, and the leg vertically.
I will have to glue these two parts,
but the final result will be stronger than if I did it in a single piece.
Plus, the printing will be faster, because not printed in heigth.


<strong><font color="Orange" size="4">µSpotLight</font></strong>



As usual you can use any 3D software to design, more over when it's based on simple shapes like this project.
In my case, I used Rhino.

If a picture is worth 1,000 words, what about an animation, it makes you thirsty...
Here is a quick'n'dirty demo how I designed the µSpotlight with Rhino.
It's not a tutorial, it's just to show how much it's an easy 3D learning exercice.

When the shapes of figures are defined by the curves, only three tools are used:

  • Extrusion
  • Boolean operation :Difference. (In order to cut out)
  • Fillet edge (on the animation you just see the unfolded menu)

Nothing more...


<strong><font color="Orange" size="4">Objectives:</font></strong>



A basic approach of CAD modeling
From the theoretical idea to get to the real object.

<strong><font color="Orange" size="4">Audience:</font></strong>



If we were 10 years ago, I would have said a project like this one can, only be made by young people starting around 18/20 years old.
Nowadays, kids are familiar with computer far younger, then we can say a project like this one can be started by kids 12 years old, maybe less, again that depends what we want to demonstrate.

<strong><font color="Orange" size="4">Skills Learned:</font></strong>


  • The goal is learning how to achieve a project, from the idea to the realisation.
    The idea will be modelised on a computer, then 3D printed, it will show every steps of the conception, and by the practical experiencing will show how to avoid mistakes.

  • The design of an object fulfills a need . It is easy to indulge in the complication in order to highlight the wealth of his own expertise , experience shows that knowledge is firstly to create a functional object , no frills , the most sober possible.

  • The anisotropic effect inherent to the 3D printing structure method.

  • Studying the material:

    • It allows to have an approach on the mechanical properties of materials . in this case the plastic . It is interesting to experiment with different types of plastic , such as , ABS, PLA, Acrylic , Nylon , and more.


<strong><font color="Orange" size="4">Duration:</font></strong>



It's always difficult to give an estimation,

  • depends on the involvement:
    • For young students, I guess a project like this one will allow to "touch" the 3D printing from the conception to the print, without going deep into each subject.
      The teacher will be there to drive the little hands.
    • For older students, I mean, from 16 years old, we can begin to go deeper into each tools and teaching.
  • Let say respectively from a day to a month.

<strong><font color="Orange" size="4">Preparation:</font></strong>


  • The students need to acces to a computer.
  • A 3D software installed.
  • Some flashlight in order to have some models to try with.
  • Bolt and screw M4x20 + screw driver
  • A 3D printer, of course.

The vertical leg is inserted by force into the base, glued for PLA, acetone for ABS.

About the large base, before to glue anything, take care about the leg <> Base orientation.
The leg bent to the outside base direction, in order to have an equilibrated supporting.
Look at the second picture to understand what I mean.

<strong><font color="Orange" size="4">Result:</font></strong>


2 kind of grip holders,

  • one, is a unique fixed diameter,
  • and the other, more flexible depends on the tightening of the screw

2 longer legs

  • long.
  • medium.

2 base shapes,

  • Round
  • Oval. (for longer torch lamp)

author: mtk

description.text:
Fan 25x25mm
Might be used for 3d assembly

Fan 30x30mm
Might be used for 3d assembly

This device feeds yout puppy if you are on holidays. Its fully automatic and only needs a new load of food all 2 weeks.

The mcu is an arduino nano, the stepper is a nema 17 with a drv8825 driver and the display is a nokia 5510 type.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kb2TypSXILU

Arduino Code 
#include <EEPROM.h>
#include <SPI.h>
#include <Adafruit_GFX.h>
#include <Adafruit_PCD8544.h>

Adafruit_PCD8544 display = Adafruit_PCD8544(5, 4, 3);

#define key_left 8
#define key_right 6
#define key_centre 7

#define stepper_enable 14
#define stepper_reset 15
#define stepper_sleep 16
#define stepper_step 17
#define stepper_dir 18

//Display
int disp = 0;
int token = 0;
byte temp_intervall = 0;
byte intervall = 0;
int erstes_intervall = 0;
unsigned long timeout = 0;
unsigned long periodic_int = 0;

int manuStepps = 10;

//EEPROM
// Adresse  Speicher
//  0        intervall in Stunden
//  1        stunden bis nächste Fütterung
unsigned long periodic_EEPROM = 3600000;  //Erster EEPROM Write nach 1h betrieb
byte hours_till_feed = 0;

void setup() {
display.begin();
  display.setContrast(60);
  delay(100);
  display.clearDisplay(); 
  display.println("Dave Feeder");
  display.display();
  delay(1500);

   pinMode(key_left, INPUT_PULLUP);
   pinMode(key_right, INPUT_PULLUP);
   pinMode(key_centre, INPUT_PULLUP);

   pinMode(stepper_enable, OUTPUT);
   pinMode(stepper_reset, OUTPUT);
   pinMode(stepper_sleep, OUTPUT);
   pinMode(stepper_step, OUTPUT);
   pinMode(stepper_dir, OUTPUT);

   digitalWrite(stepper_reset,HIGH);
   disableStepper();

   //EEPROM auslesen
   intervall = temp_intervall = EEPROM.read(0);
   timeout = (EEPROM.read(1)*3600000)+millis();
}

void loop() {
//Welcher Button?
  if(!token){
    if(!digitalRead(key_left)){disp =key_left; display.clearDisplay();display.println("Fuetterung");display.display();  token = 1;}
    else if(!digitalRead(key_right)){disp =key_right;display.clearDisplay();display.println("Up  Run  Down");
                                      display.drawLine(0, 11, 84, 11, BLACK);display.println(" ");
                                      display.drawLine(18, 0, 18, 11, BLACK); display.drawLine(46, 0, 46, 11, BLACK);
                                      display.println("manuell");display.println("Schritte");display.println("fahren");display.display(); token = 1;delay(500);

                                      }
    else if(!digitalRead(key_centre)){disp =key_centre;display.clearDisplay();display.println("Up   OK  Down");display.drawLine(0, 11, 84, 11, BLACK);
                                      display.drawLine(25, 0, 25, 11, BLACK); display.drawLine(46, 0, 46, 11, BLACK);display.println(" ");display.println("SetzeInterval");
                                      display.display();token = 1;delay(500);}
  }

  //Button Funktion Ausführen
  switch (disp) {
    //Fütterung Ausführen
    case key_left:
      if(token){
        enableStepper();
        delay(20);
        for(int i = 0 ; i<200 ; i++)
        {
           digitalWrite(stepper_step,LOW);
           stepDelay();
           digitalWrite(stepper_step,HIGH);
           stepDelay();
        }
        disableStepper();
        token=token -1;
      }
    break; 

    //Manual Mode
    case key_right:
      if(token){
        if(!digitalRead(key_left))
        {
          manuStepps = manuStepps + 10;
          display.clearDisplay();
          display.println("Up  Run  Down");
          display.drawLine(0, 11, 84, 11, BLACK);display.println(" ");
          display.drawLine(18, 0, 18, 11, BLACK); display.drawLine(46, 0, 46, 11, BLACK);
          display.print(manuStepps);
          display.println(" Schritte");
          display.println("fahren");
         display.display();
          delay(200);
          }
        if(!digitalRead(key_right))
        {
          manuStepps = manuStepps - 10;
          display.clearDisplay();
          display.println("Up  Run  Down");
          display.drawLine(0, 11, 84, 11, BLACK);display.println(" ");
          display.drawLine(18, 0, 18, 11, BLACK); display.drawLine(46, 0, 46, 11, BLACK);
          display.print(manuStepps);
          display.println(" Schritte");
          display.println("fahren");
          display.display();
          delay(200);
          }
        if(!digitalRead(key_centre))
        {   
        enableStepper();
        delay(20);
        int tempManuStepps;
        if(manuStepps<0){
             digitalWrite(stepper_dir,HIGH);}

        for(int i = 0 ; i<abs(manuStepps) ; i++)
        {
           digitalWrite(stepper_step,LOW);
           stepDelay();
           digitalWrite(stepper_step,HIGH);
           stepDelay();
        }
        disableStepper();
        token=0;
        digitalWrite(stepper_dir,LOW);
        delay(400);
       }
      }
    break;

    //Intervall Einstellen
    case key_centre:
      if(token){
        if(!digitalRead(key_left))
        {
          temp_intervall++;
          display.clearDisplay();
          display.println("Up   OK  Down");
          display.drawLine(0, 11, 84, 11, BLACK);display.println(" ");
          display.drawLine(25, 0, 25, 11, BLACK); display.drawLine(46, 0, 46, 11, BLACK);
          display.print(temp_intervall);
          display.println(" Stunden");
          display.println("Intervall");
         display.display();
          delay(200);
          }
        if(!digitalRead(key_right))
        {
          temp_intervall--;
          display.clearDisplay();
          display.println("Up   OK  Down");
          display.drawLine(0, 11, 84, 11, BLACK);display.println(" ");
          display.drawLine(25, 0, 25, 11, BLACK); display.drawLine(46, 0, 46, 11, BLACK);
          display.print(temp_intervall);
          display.println(" Stunden");
          display.println("Intervall");
          display.display();
          delay(200);
          }
        if(!digitalRead(key_centre))
        {   
          intervall = temp_intervall;
          EEPROM.write(0,intervall);
          EEPROM.write(1,intervall);
          token=0;
          timeout = (intervall*3600000)+millis();
          delay(400);
         }
       }
    break;
    default: 
    break;}

  //Display Update 1x pro sekunde    
  if(millis()>=periodic_int)
  {
    periodic_int = millis()+1000;
    unsigned long time_till_feed = (timeout-millis())/60000;
    if(!token){
            //Standard Display
            display.clearDisplay();
            display.println("Run  Zeit Man");
            display.drawLine(0, 11, 84, 11, BLACK);
            display.drawLine(23, 0, 23, 11, BLACK);
            display.drawLine(56, 0, 56, 11, BLACK);
            display.println(" ");
            if(intervall){
              display.println("Naechste");
              display.println("Fuetterung in");
              display.print( time_till_feed );
              display.println("min");}
            else 
            //Kein Intervall gesetzt
            {
              display.println("Intervall eingeben");
            }  
            display.display();
            }

      if(millis()>=timeout)
      {
        if(intervall){
          //Feed
          disp =key_left; display.clearDisplay();display.println("Fütterung");display.display();
          token = 3; //Number of feedingturns 
          timeout = (intervall*3600000)+millis();
      }}

  }

  //EEPROM Save. 1x Pro Stunde 
  if(millis()>=periodic_EEPROM && intervall)
  {
    periodic_EEPROM = millis()+3600000;
    hours_till_feed = (byte)(((timeout-millis())/3600000)+0.5);
    EEPROM.write(0,intervall);
    EEPROM.write(1,hours_till_feed);
  }

}

void enableStepper()
{
    digitalWrite(stepper_enable,LOW);
    digitalWrite(stepper_sleep,HIGH);
    //digitalWrite(stepper_reset,HIGH);
}
void disableStepper()
{
    digitalWrite(stepper_enable,HIGH);
    digitalWrite(stepper_sleep,LOW);
    //digitalWrite(stepper_reset,LOW);
}
void stepDelay()
{
    delayMicroseconds(1000);
}

description.text: I wanted to mount a sound bar (VIZIO SB3821-C6) under my fireplace mantle without drilling into the tile behind it. This is designed to screw into the wood mantle vertically and allow the sound bar to float below. This would probably also work as a wall mount or as a foot to elevate one of these sound bars on a flat surface if mounted the other way around.

Printer:

Rigidbot Big

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print with at least 3 loops, laying down flat. No support should really be needed.

I measured the sound bar with calipers at about 66.5mm square, and rounded up to 77 for clearance. Then measured the radius of the rounded corners at 5mm, rounded up to 5.5 for clearance. I modeled a dummy of the bar in 123 and filet-ed the edges, then duplicated it and scaled the duplicate up by a factor of 1.05. Subtract the smaller from the larger. I pulled the top up and tweaked 3 sides inward, then subtracted a couple of 4m and 20mm cylinders offset from the center on the remaining top surface areas to create a screw hole and screwdriver clearance. I chamfered the corners left from subtracting the cylinders, and tweaked inward on a couple more points that looked structurally weak.

title: Microphone Shock  Mount for Ikea Lamp

description.text:
Cleaned up and modified version of pdrengers's very good remix of marsCubed's original design that now fit directly on an Ikea Tertial lamp so the swivel and tilt still works. No needs no additional hardware beyond rubber bands.(See NOTE below)
Credit to milokp too for the idea of mounting it directly on a lamp.

  • Print model, I use 3 perimeters, 3 top and bottom layers, 25% infill in grey ABS. But I'm sure you can get away with less. No supports, nice easy print.
  • Cut and pull out wires from lamp(Use to pull through microphone cable if it fits?), remove globe base. Retain bolts.
  • NOTE: There seems to be two versions of this lamp, the most common uses longer M4 bolts but some see to come with shorter M3's. The M4's will work fine, the M3's will need to be replaced with longer bolts for this to work. The only difference seems to be the bolts.
  • Using original bolts if long enough, attach new shock mount holder. Holes may need to be cleaned out with a drill or file, depending on your printer. Star washes under the nuts inside the holder. If you need the extra space, you can install the bolts backwards(With heads inside and nuts outside) but it looks ugly.
  • Use rubber bands(cheap but degrade quickly) or silicon or polyurethane hair bands(Harder to find but work better), avoid cloth coated ones, these make noise when they rub together, to create the web of your choice, install microphone.
  • BONUS: Find a use for the original lamp holder and shade. Hanging lamp? Funnel? Maybe someone else has an idea? :)

title: Half-Kilo Spool Holder - for Monoprice Select Mini

description.text:
The Monoprice Select Mini is a cheap yet quite capable 3D printer, with terrible manufacturing quality control :). Seriously, many people who buy it have probs with manufacturing errors. Mine had crimp connector without a conductor in it, and display has artifacts right from the start. Others report quickly-failing power supplies.

But with the very low price ($200-ish) and the excellent print quality (once tuned) it's hard to argue with it. It's most suitable for those with some electronics career experience. (The unit is manufactured and sold under other names too.)

The spool holder for your filament, while it fits a 1kg spool okay, doesn't fit the half-kilo spool I bought recently.

So this is a holder that will slip over the existing one, and support your half-kilo spool.

There are two little tabs on the metal spool holder that need to be bent out of the way. Caution though, those tabs keep the big spool away from the housing. Ensure you use a spacer when you're using your 1kg spool to keep it from snagging the unit housing. I find there is enough 'sag' to the metal holder than the spool stays away from the unit anyway, but just-sayin'.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Seems nicely rigid and functional with 25% fill, and .2mm resolution was enough for a nice clean result.

Note that it prints at a 45º angle on the print-surface to fit on the Mini's smaller bed.

Part photo attached is a v1 print. The v2 .STL file attached has a few improvements (like the slight up-tilt to counteract strut angle) and a dimensional fix.

Fit to the MP Select Mini's Existing spool holder

The existing spool holder has a couple of poke-out tabs near the unit. These keep a regular 1kg spool away from the housing. Some spools can snag on the unit potentially, so having a spacer here is a good idea. Perhaps print yourself a little chunk to stick in here after you've bent the tabs out of the way, so this half-spool holder will slide over the metal strut.

Use a spacer when you're not using your half-kilo spool, and you'll be okay.

Notes

Made the unit with a slight tilt-back because the metal holder strut leans down a tad. The bend-back cancels out the lean.

Made for a half-kilo spool that has a hub-hole of about 32mm.

title: GoPro/ SJ4000/ Turnigy 2K Action Cam Mount

description.text:
Basic camera mount for top mount on a quadcopter, 25 degree cam angle. Use 2 sided tape and zip ties for attachment, and a battery strap for fastening the camera to the mount. Use some grippy foam tape on the mounting surface if you want to help the camera stay in place better in crashes.

This mount is 36mm wide, so it should fit within the width of most racing drone top plates. It sets a little high, the quad I made it for needed prop clearance to keep the corners of my GoPro safe, should still work fine for any other frame.

If you want it, message me and I'll send you the part file for Solidworks.

Update 8/23/16

Added second file labeled V5 that has a pass through for a second strap for extra security. We won't talk about why... The single strap works fine until you crash in wet grass and your so-called "grippy" strap gets wet.

Update 8/23/16

Added a few pics of the V2 mount and added a V6 file. The V6 makes better use of strap length. I honestly have a tinkering problem and should seek help. I'll post pics of strap routing for that one soon.

Update 12/3/16

Deleted obsolete versions, will have finalized(ish) version to upload soon.

description.text:
Le "Sphéro Baby Foot" a été réalisé par des élèves au FABLAB de Sarreguemines FABULIS (www.fabulis.org).

Le Fablab est dans un lycée, il est géré par des élèves en situation de handicap ( ULIS pro).

Le "Sphéro Baby Foot" permet a tous les utilisateurs du fablab de faire des matchs et ainsi de s'amuser tout en apprenant à programer avec la Sphéro et l'App Tickle.

Les pièces ont été imprimées sur une Makerbot 5G par les élèves de l'ULIS pro et ont été dessinées sur Solidworks par les élèves du Lycée.

The FabLab is a high school, it is run by students with disabilities (ULIS pro).

The "Sphero Baby Foot" allows everything fablab the user to make games and so have fun while learning a programer with Sphero and Tickle App.

Parts have was printed on a Makerbot 5G by the students of the ULIS pro and were drawn on Solidworks by High School students.

De 7 à 77 ans, collèges et lycées.

Conception Mécanique : comment faire pour maintenir en position les tasseaux de bois ?

Mechanical Design: how to maintain position in the cleats of wood?

exemple de règle du jeux

Règles du Baby Foot Sphéro

Age conseillé des joueurs :

de 7 à 77 ans

Nombre de joueurs :

1 contre 1 ; 2 contre 2 ou 1 contre 2

Le matériel :

voir tableau annexe

Le but du jeu :

La première équipe qui marque 5 points remporte le match.
Un But est égal à 1 point.

Le début du jeu :

La partie commence par un tirage au sort. L’engagement (joueur ayant bénéficié du tirage au sort) se fait devant le gardien de but de l’équipe qui engage.

Les règles :

Les équipes attaquent à tour de rôle, l’équipe qui attaque a 5 min pour marquer un but, quand l’équipe marque avant la fin des 5 min, elle passe la sphèro et la tablette à l’équipe adverse.

L’équipe qui défend a 2min pour positionner ses joueurs en défense.

L’équipe qui attaque peut faire glisser ses joueurs sur le côté du terrain.

Les joueurs qui attaquent peuvent manipuler leur gardien, les défenseurs et les milieux de terrain.

Les joueurs qui défendent peuvent manipuler leur gardien, les défenseurs, les milieux de terrain et les attaquants.

Les interdits :

Toute tentative de distraction.
Avoir une attitude agressive à l’égard des adversaires.

Rules Baby Foot Sphero

Age recommended players:

7 to 77 years

Number of players:

1 against 1; 2 against 2 or 2 against 1

Equipment :

see attached

The aim of the game :

The first team to score five points wins.
One Goal is equal to 1 point.

The beginning:

The section begins with a draw. The commitment (player who benefited from the draw) is done before the team goalkeeper commits.

The rules :

The teams attacking in turn, the attacking team has 5 minutes to score a goal when the team scores before the end of 5 minutes, it passes the Sphero and tablet to the opposing team.

The defending team has 2min to position his players on defense.

The attacking team can drag his players on the wing.

Players can manipulate their attacking goalkeeper, defenders and midfielders.

Players can manipulate their defending goalkeeper, defenders, midfielders and attackers.

Prohibitions :

Any attempt to distraction.
Have an aggressive attitude against opponents.

Duration:

4 x 2h

Preparation:

débutant

beginner

Rubric & Assessment:

Pas d'évaluation, on est plus en 1930 ;)

No rating, we are not in 1930 ;)

author: Fabulis

description.text: Students in a 5th grade classroom learn about plant and animal cells. Students learned how to tell the difference between a plant and animal cell and could compare and contrast the two. Students worked on TinkerCAD to create one of the types of cells. They worked to make sure their cell included the different cell parts and the correct proportions and shape that is characteristic of that cell.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

*Tips & Tricks
• Before printing it's important to go through each student's design to ensure that their creations are printable. For example: We often had students who created parts of their cell that "floated" above other parts instead of actually being connected. Doing a quick check that objects are correctly layered and designed will help immensely when it comes down to printing.
• We made sure that if the students created their animal cell with a spherical shape that we cut the bottom of it to make it flat so that it both printed better and then had a bottom to sit on when on display.
• We also printed multiple cells on a build plate at a time. It cut down on printing time and allowed the printer to run all day instead of shorter prints that needed to constantly be started throughout the day.

Peer Checks

After the student's had their printed cells they partnered up with someone and each partner worked to identify the different parts of their partner's cell to test their knowledge.

TinkerCAD

Students use the TinkerCAD website to create both their plant and animal cells.
CCSS

Students learn about plant and animal cells and the basic structures of each. Students need to know how to compare and contrast these two types of cells.  Students also need to understand the function of each important structure in the cells such as the nucleus, cytoplasm, and the cell membrane or wall.  When designing these cells students needed to depict the basic shape of the cell as well as the major structures.  Students had to ensure that all of the cell structures were designed according to their correct placement and size within the cell.

Students should be able to identify the different types of cells: plant and animal based on structure, size, and shape.  Students should also be able to identify the important structure within each type of cell and explain how it’s function is vital to the cell.

Virginia SOL: Science SOL 5.5a
The student will investigate and understand that organisms are made of cells and have distinguishing characteristics. Key concepts include:
a) basic cell structures and functions Common Core:
(Common Core Standard) 6-8.RS.4 Determine the meaning of symbols, key terms, and other domain-specific words and phrases as they are used in a specific scientific context relevant to grades 6-8 texts and topics. (Content Standard) SCI.7.3.1 2010 Explain that all living organisms are composed of one cell or multiple cells and that the many functions needed to sustain life are carried out within cells.

• In class students learn about plant and animal cells unit. Throughout the unit, students identify and understand the important structures of each type of cell and their function. Students understand the basic shape of each type of cell and where the structures can be found within the cell.
  • Students log onto TinkerCAD and learn the basics of 3D design such as grouping, layering, and creating holes.
  • Students are given the chance to choose which type of cell they want to create.
  • Then students create a drawn draft of what they want to create. Students need to make sure their cell drawings are complete with the cell’s correct shape, physical features, important structures, and that everything is proportional.
  • After the student’s draft is approved by the teacher they may begin working in TinkerCAD.
  • Students use TinkerCAD and begin creating their model of the cell they chose.
  • Once students finish the teacher needs to ensure that the creation has all of the components and is ready for printing.
After students learned about the cell unit in class the actual 3D modeling and creating part took the students two 30-minute computer lab times.

Before beginning in TinkerCAD students need to understand the two major types of cells: plant and animal cells.  Students need to have the background knowledge of the cell structure and the different parts within the cell.  Students also need to be able to log into TinkerCAD and create objects, holes, and group items.

Please see the attached documents for our handouts and assessments.
As a handout to learn the vocabulary we use these word wall cards from: https://sites.google.com/a/solteacher.com/olteacher-com/home/fifth-grade/fifth-grade-science-sol-5th/science-sol-5-5a/cell-structures-sol-5-5a We also use these label pages to help students understand the plant parts. Some teachers use this handout as a quiz document as well from:
http://www.enchantedlearning.com/subjects/biology/cells/ By the end of the project students should have designed either a plant or animal cell including its important parts. Students will get full credit on their 3D creations if they ensure that their cell the appropriate size, features, and parts.

Brain Pop Intro Lesson:
https://educators.brainpop.com/bp-topic/cells/ Cell Lessons and Resources:
https://sites.google.com/a/solteacher.com/olteacher-com/home/fifth-grade/fifth-grade-science-sol-5th/science-sol-5-5a

author: huyhoang

title: Digital caliper bed levelling jig for Rep (remix)

description.text:
It is a remix of Willfly's great design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:455050
I took his idea (and Rhino's file) and adapted the thing to be used in a clone of a Replicator 2.
What I did:

  • Increased the arms' distance.
  • Lowered the screw's wall so it can fit easier.
  • Modified a little bit the canals under the arms so the toothed belt could fit properly.

UPDATE: after playing with this thing for a few minutes I didn't find it very useful. I think it is not accurate enough for the task. A little bit of a bummer. Let me know your opinion.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Curl effect in the arms was a pain in the neck. Take into account that the surface of the thing in contact with the bed is quite small so make sure it has good adherence. Anyway I must admit it is a common problem in my prints that I am trying to solve...
I didn't try using raft but it could help.
Mouse ears in the design could also turn to be a bullet proof solution.

The original model didn't need support. Neither this one but not using support may generate some bridges.
Printing time: 1h 22m
Filament: 6.0145 m (1.75mm diam)

comments.text:

author: slyfox110

title: GEAR SEATS MOTION JEEP GRAND CHEROKEE ZJ (ENGRENAGEM DE MOVIMENTO DOS ASSENTOS JEEP GRAND CHEROKEE ZJ)

description.text:
This is my first contribution ...

I have a Jeep Grand Chekokee Limited in 1997.

Since I bought the car, some electrical functions of movement of the seats were not working, although you could hear the engines working.

After disassembling found that some gears of the axes of motion were broken.

With the help of a good friend (thanks, Odacir!), We design the new gear.

Perhaps the United States is easy to get a repair kit for this, but here in Brazil unfortunately we do not have much to these cars, though there are many running around here.

So just remove the broken gears and the subsitui printed. To paste the endless axes, I used superglue.

It was printed on PLA with 0.2mm layer and 90% fill.

Essa é a minha primeira contribuição...

Eu tenho um Jeep Grand Chekokee Limited 1997.

Desde que comprei o carro, algumas funções elétricas de movimento dos assentos não estavam funcionando, embora se ouvia os motores trabalhando.

Após desmontar constatei que algumas engrenagens dos eixos de movimento estavam quebradas.

Com ajuda de um grande amigo (obrigado, Odacir!), desenhamos a engrenagem nova.

Talvez nos Estados Unidos seja fácil conseguir um kit de reparo para isso, mas aqui no Brasil infelizmente não dispomos de muita coisa para esses carros, embora existam muitos rodando por aqui.

Então é só retirar as engrenagens quebradas e subsitui pelas impressas. Para colar no eixos sem fim, usei supercola.

Foi impresso em PLA com camada de 0.2mm e 90% de preenchimento.

description.text:
Students in a 5th grade classroom were learning about the different geographic features of the ocean floor. Students had to be able to identify the following features:
Continental shelf, Continental slope, Continental rise, abyssal floor, seamounts, mid-Atlantic ridge, and trench.
Once the students were familiar with these features they worked to create a replica of the ocean floor including each of the important features.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

*Tips & Tricks:

  • Before printing it's important to go through each student's design to ensure that their creations are printable. For example: We often had student's who created seamounts however parts of them "floated" above the ocean floor instead of actually being connected. Doing a quick check that objects are correctly layered and designed will help immensely when it comes down to printing.
  • We also printed multiple ocean floors on a build plate at a time. It cut down on printing time and allowed the printer to run all day instead of shorter prints that needed to constantly be started throughout the day.

TinkerCAD

Students worked on TinkerCAD to create their layers of the ocean floor.
CCSS

Students learn about the different geographic layers of the ocean floor. Students need to be able to recognize the different geographic features and where they can be found in the ocean. Students learned about plate tectonics and how each feature was formed. Students need to be able to identify the following geographic features:
Continental shelf, Continental slope, Continental rise, abyssal floor, seamounts, mid-Atlantic ridge, and trench.
After students knew enough to identify the different features of the ocean floor they worked in TinkerCAD to design their own ocean floors. They were allowed to make the ocean floor look however they wanted as long as they had all of the above parts and they were accurately depicted.

Students should be able to identify the different geologic features of the ocean floor: Continental shelf, Continental slope, Continental rise, abyssal floor, seamounts, mid-Atlantic ridge, and trench.  Students should be able to design the ocean floor with the correct geographic features in terms of spacing and proportion.

Skills Learned (Standards):
Virginia SOL: Standard Science SOL 5.6a
The student will investigate and understand characteristics of the ocean environment. Key concepts include: a) geological characteristics (continental shelf, slope, rise) Common Core:
http://coreknowledge.org/mimik/mimik_uploads/lesson_plans/1425/6_EarthWaterPlanet.pdf

• In class students learn about the geography of the ocean floor unit. Throughout the unit, students identify and understand the different geologic features of the ocean floor: Continental shelf, Continental slope, Continental rise, abyssal floor, seamounts, mid-Atlantic ridge, and trench.
  • Students log onto TinkerCAD and learn the basics of 3D design such as grouping, layering, and creating holes.
  • Then students create a drawn draft of what they want to create and how they are going to include each feature into their ocean floor. Students need to make sure their ocean floor drawings are complete with the correct physical features and proportions.
  • After the student’s draft is approved by the teacher they may begin working in TinkerCAD.
  • Students use TinkerCAD and begin creating their model of the ocean floor.
  • Once students finish the teacher needs to ensure that the creation has all of the components and is ready for printing.
After students started learning about the ocean floor unit in class the actual 3D modeling and creating part took the students about an hour to complete.

Before beginning in TinkerCAD students need to understand the geography of the ocean floor. They must be able to identify the different geologic features of the ocean floor: Continental shelf, Continental slope, Continental rise, abyssal floor, seamounts, mid-Atlantic ridge, and trench.

By the end of the project students should have designed the bottom of the ocean floor including its important features. Students will get full credit on their 3D creations if they ensure that their ocean floor contains each of the features and they are correctly placed. Please see the attached documents for our handouts and assessments.
Here are some good ideas for lessons: https://www.cpet.ufl.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Mapping-the-Ocean-Floor-Worksheet-and-Lab-Activity.pdf

https://educators.brainpop.com/bp-topic/ocean-floor/ Ocean Lessons and Resources:
https://sites.google.com/a/solteacher.com/olteacher-com/home/fifth-grade/fifth-grade-science-sol-5th/geological-characteristics

description.text:
Two-thousand pounds of copper and tin cast by John Pass and John Stow, the bell was created to commemorate the first reading of the Declaration of Independence on July 8, 1776. The crack occurred seventy years later on George Washington's birthday, as a result of a previous imperfection which had been repaired. The bell has since been adopted as an iconic symbol for independence and liberty, and thus termed, "The Liberty Bell."

This 3D print will show the words for larger-sized prints. The words are as follows:

Pass and Stow
Philadelphia
MDCCLII

and at the top, it says, "Proclaim Liberty through all the land unto all inhabitants thereof,"
from the Book of Leviticus.

All were designed in-house at the Winnetka-Northfield Public Library District:

The Winnetka-Northfield Public Library District is home to a wonderful makerspace, known as The Studio, that is open to all; for this challenge, library staff banded together with ideas and possible entries for this competition. We have observed many schools and individuals entering Thingiverse's competitions, but have yet to see a library...until now! Many of these ideas and designs were inspired for our makerspace and remodeled youth department

More about the Library District and The Studio:

The Winnetka-Northfield Public Library District is a community resource for the advancement of knowledge, and a provider of innovative and informative cultural enrichment for all ages.

The Studio is made possible by a generous gift given to the Library from the Staffileno Family, in order that the library create a space to honor the memory of Constance E. Staffileno. The Studio was created to embody Mrs. Staffileno’s love for art and art education, and to inspire generations of innovators and art enthusiasts.Located in the lower level of the Winnetka Library, The Studio features the latest technology and equipment, such as 3D printers, Adobe Creative Cloud software and a laser engraver, as well as classic art mediums like paint and canvas, to inspire and educate a community of artistic makers and creators.

title: Mojo Raspberry Pi Zero docking Station

description.text:
This is a Chord Mojo docking station with a Raspberry Pi Zero. Charge your Mojo, stream music, create a media server.

I use a minimal linux version from rune audio (http://www.runeaudio.com/) to stream music from my nas to the Mojo, using my tablet with bubbleupnp to control the dnla renderer.

Of course you can use any Linux version that works with the Raspberry Pi Zero.

Hardware:

2 micro usb male plugs
1 Raspberry Pi Zero 1.3 board
1 HubPiWi 1.3 board
1 8 gb micro sd card with rune audio image

Soldering experience for small parts needed, experience with the Raspberry (flash sd card, setting up, config adjustments).

Look at http://www.runeaudio.com/forum/raspberry-pi-zero-support-in-0-4-t3711.html for Rune Audio and Raspberry Pi Zero.

title: Geometric Gardening: Winnetka-Northfield Public Library District

description.text:
Gardening is extremely fun and practical topic. With the geometric garden planters designed here, a classroom or learning/makerspace can teach, not only about math and unique geometric shapes, but also about gardening/plant life as well. A double-wammy!

This project is a favorite for its ability to bring together various STEAM topics!

Included are: a hexagonal, spherical, and hyperbolic planters! Yay!

Gardening, similar to 3D printing, can be used for experiential learning and community engagement -especially when we use gardening to assist with feeding communities throughout our area or region!

All were designed in-house at the Winnetka-Northfield Public Library District:

The Winnetka-Northfield Public Library District is home to a wonderful makerspace, known as The Studio, that is open to all; for this challenge, library staff banded together with ideas and possible entries for this competition. We have observed many schools and individuals entering Thingiverse's competitions, but have yet to see a library...until now! Many of these ideas and designs were inspired for our makerspace and remodeled youth department

More about the Library District and The Studio:

The Winnetka-Northfield Public Library District is a community resource for the advancement of knowledge, and a provider of innovative and informative cultural enrichment for all ages.

The Studio is made possible by a generous gift given to the Library from the Staffileno Family, in order that the library create a space to honor the memory of Constance E. Staffileno. The Studio was created to embody Mrs. Staffileno’s love for art and art education, and to inspire generations of innovators and art enthusiasts.Located in the lower level of the Winnetka Library, The Studio features the latest technology and equipment, such as 3D printers, Adobe Creative Cloud software and a laser engraver, as well as classic art mediums like paint and canvas, to inspire and educate a community of artistic makers and creators.

If you have any questions, feel free to email us at [email protected]

description.text:
Nema 17 servo mount for auto bed leveling.

I am working on a version 2 and 3, V2 is a bit thicker V3 is also thicker but also has the mount for the servo off set so it can get the end stop arm closer to the hot end plus a few extra angles pieces make the servo mount stronger and to keep it from wobbling. Once I comfortable with the design and it works on my machine I will upload both versions.

description.text:
A simple bolt cap to hide the head of a bolt.

The size of the cap is calculated at printing time, with an internal reference size of 14mm.
Measure your bolt at the maximum size (see photo 3) and divide with 14mm, then you have the scaling factor.

Example: My bolt maximum WIDTH is 14.7mm, Scaling: 14.7/14= 1.05.
Designed using FreeCAD

print_settings.Notes:: To prevent support structures from clogging the holes in Haunter's head, I recommend printing his head upside down. Also, a raft might help the insane amount of necessary support to adhere to the bed.

title: Haunter with Eyes and Floating Stand (Pokemon)

description.text:
Haunter, modified with eyes and optimized to fit in an included stand. Print the stand in clear filament for best results. Tolerances of .1mm factored in to the stand pegs and holes already. After placing on the stand, Haunter will be stationary but the hands will be able to turn to whatever angles you want.

UPDATE:

At the advice of Talcys, I've updated the files for the head and stand to increase the tolerances and make the pegs for the hands longer.

Notes:

To prevent support structures from clogging the holes in Haunter's head, I recommend printing his head upside down. Also, a raft might help the insane amount of necessary support to adhere to the bed.

comments.text: So I printed this, and there are several issues with it. First, the stand pins for the hands aren't long enough. The angle for the hole in the hands doesn't allow them to slide onto the pin, they hit the stand. Second, the front and rear pin for the head line up, but the left and right pins don't line up. The pins are also very tight, I needed to do a lot of drilling to get all pieces to fit together. It looks really sweet once it's together, but hopefully with some revisions it'll work better :)

author: MaddieLee3D

description.text:
This is a small handle for standard 1/4" screwdriver bits. It's incredibly handy for getting into tiny spaces that are too short for a standard screwdriver.

This was inspired by 4 Volt's Small Hex Screwdriver Handle. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:137367 Thanks 4 Volt!

The big change in this vs. 4 volt's model is the smaller size. The total height with a bit installed is 1.1 inches/28mm. Additionally I've added a small through hole so bits can be pushed out using a small pin or nail. The Bit size and clearance are parameterized in the Fusion 360 model if you need to fit a different sized hex bit or want to adjust the clearance for a looser fit.

The example model was printed with a 0.1mm layer height 50% infill in MonoPrice PLA. The part was designed in AutoDesk Fusion 360. .STL, F3D, STEP, and IGES files are attached.

Printer:

MP Select Mini 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

50%
Autodesk Fusion 360

comments.text: Works perfectly for taking off the body panel screws on my car where there's very little space. The tolerance for the hole was very tight so if i were to print this again I would do so at 101%. Thanks for making this! The hole for bit extraction was a really good idea.

comments.author: kolik69

comments.text: I have done a similar design, incorporating a control unit, two heat sinks, and two fans. this is a start, but realistically does much better with heat sinks on both sides of the peltier component, and more air over the hot side than the cold. In essence the peltier Thero-electric cooling component(TEC)  simply uses energy to transfer heat energy from one side to the other. This is arguably not a great method, try using a water cooled heat sink for the hot side, and a simple aluminum heat sink for the cold side, you will have a much more satisfying Air cooling unit.

title: Engineering WORKBENCH - Drill Press , Table Saw , Tools

description.text:
I have seen an assortment of Tool Assemblies across the thgivrs and internet. So I decided to put all of the Tools together into one Large WorkBench. This is a WorkBench incorporating a DrillPress and a CircularSaw, and Multiple Expansion arms for additional Tools. The WorkBench sizes to about 18-inches by 10-inches by 12-inches.

  • Drill-Press (on leftside)
  • Circular-Saw / Router (on rightside)
  • Work Table (in center)

All Tools have:

  • Rear X-Adjustment via Rear Main Horizontal Rods,
  • Z-Vertical Rear Rod Adjustment,
  • X/Y Positoning Arms.

All the Tools are easily removed and Re-mounted on the Rear-Rods.

All Wing-Screws are used to allow the User / Engineer to raise/lower the Tools on the Rear Vertical Rods. There are Wing-Screws that allow the Arms to loosen to adjust X/Y-Distance. Also Adjustments for Tool-Tilt.

This can be done starting from the Frame , then adding Modular Pieces: Rear-Vertical-Rods with Arm and Tool-Mount.

The Bottom Frame as pictured here - will be replaced (is in the current process of) by a Rod supported Base.

This uses #6 1/2-inch and 3/4-inch Screws.
Also, #6 3/4-inch Wing-Bolts are used for User adjusting.
The Rods are 1/4-inch Steel-Rod from home-depot or lowes.

Also see:
1744117 - Engineering WORKBENCH - Table Saw

This is a Project in continuous Improvement and Mods - Under Construction.

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel

Doesn't Matter

0.2mm - 0.8mm Nozzle Tips

printed these on a Mendel RepRap with 1.75mm fibre. I used a 0.8mm Nozzle Tip with 0.5mm Layer Height setting. Can use any tip from 0.2mm to 0.8mm should print fine. It took between 20-90 minutes per part to print.

Some Parts may have burrs -and need filing to finish.
If the bolts seem loose, gluegun may help.
Used TinkerCad.

title: It’s a 3d printer Object? It’s a Fruit? Oh, Maybe it’s an insect!!!

description.text:
Insects are all around us in many environments. Entomology is the science that study insects and the entomologist is the scientist who studies insects.
It’s a 3d printer Object? It’s a Fruit? Oh, maybe it’s an Insect!!! It’s a project that aims engage and educate students towards science, technology, nature and mathematics.
The project include 6 activities/challenges for your students.
The children will be invited to play the role of entomologists and perform mini-inquiry challenges and hands on activities.
With this project students can discover the fascinating world of insects.

Printer:

BQ Witbox

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

To design this project I used Tinkercad. Tinkercad is an easy-to-use 3D CAD design tool.

Dragonfly

To draw the dragonfly I used 2 spheres for the wings and a pyramid. For “face” I draw three spheres. To the end of the body I draw three cylinders and one pyramid.

There are many species of dragonfly, so you can use another type of wings to obtain another type of 3d object (see image). It’s the same kind of object with a different configuration.

Ladybug

Head and wings
to draw Ladybug I used for the wings two half spheres and seven spheres in each wing. For the insect face I draw two cylinder, two paraboloid and two spheres.
Legs
For one of the legs: I draw 3 circular trapezoid, one tube that I cut with a paraboloid. I draw a paraboloid and a pyramid.
For the second leg I copy the first leg then I retire the paraboloid. For the third leg I draw a cylinder, with another cylinder I make a hole and I used part of the other legs to finish.

Butterfly and caterpillar

To draw the antennae I used cylinders and spheres. For the “face” I draw a sphere, two spheres for the eyes and for the proboscis I used the symbol @. To draw the butterfly wings I used a circular trapezoid in two different position and with a different configuration:
For the caterpillar I used the” face” of the ladybug but I replace the cylinder for one paraboloid. Then, I made the segments of the body.

Ant

For the ant head I used cylinders, a sphere for the “face”, two spheres for the eyes and parts of a thin tube for the mouth parts.
For the ant legs I used cylinders and for the abdomen I draw half of a sphere and a cone.

Spider and Scorpion

For the design of the spider I draw the legs with cylinders and a half sphere. For the abdomen I used one paraboloid and a half of a sphere.
For the head I draw some modifications to the original project. I made the head round and join the chelicerae (mouth parts). For eyes I used spheres.
I used for scorpion the same kind of legs but then I realized that the shape of the legs was not very well and changed the legs to the STL file. In the stinger I used spheres and donuts.

Other Insect

For this insect o used for the legs paraboloids and cylinders and I show in images part of the process.

Beehive: honeycomb, Queen Bee, Drone, Worker bee

For the bee hive I design one hexagon. I duplicate them and I decrease one of them. Than place another hexagon inside the first to make a hole and group then I group objects.
The hexagon I draw isn´t absolutely perfect.

Bee Life Cycle

For the bee life cycle I draw an egg with an egg. I draw the larvae with spheres and torus and the pupa I made a copy of the adult but I retire the legs. I make another copy of the adult and I decrease them.

Ant Life Cycle

For the ant life cycle I used the same strategy.

Butterfly Life Cycle

I use the same wings with a cylinder, a sphere for the head and two spheres for the eyes. The caterpillar o draw a sphere, donuts, and another sphere and I used the head of the butterfly. The chrysalis I used parts of the caterpillar and I retire the head.

description.header: It's a 3d printer object? It's a Fruit? Oh! Maybe It's an Insect!!!
description.text:
Project Name

It’s a 3-D printer Object? It’s a Fruit? Oh, maybe it’s an Insect!!! Aims students perform inquiry and hands on science activities. They has potentiality to increase the creative and scientific thinking of kids. The projects aims increase the curiosity about science issues. This project aims to inspire students for science.

Overview & Background

This project is an opportunity to build into practice some of the educational activities and ideas that have to do with my background: biology (scientific training) / museology education/didactics of science education and a 16-year work experience in a center of science and technology / museum. I like to draw, I like to learn and I try to understand how people learn. I also like museums, science and hand 's on activities, 3D printer and stl file design. I started using tinkercad newly. With this project I try to improve my skills in 3D design and I hope to improve my English which is unfortunately it's not very good.

Objectives

• Understand key ideas related to the topic: Insects and their relatives haven’t the same characteristics.
• Understand insects belong with their relatives to the group called Arthropods.
• Understand Arthropoda is subdivided in other groups.
Arachnida: spiders, scorpions (and others)
Insecta: Lady-bug, bee, wasp
Another groups (it’s not important students know all. You should explain if students have curiosity.)
• Recognize what is an insect
• Recognize the spider and the scorpion aren't insects
• Play the role of entomologists and perform mini investigations
• Know more about bees and the math in nature
• Perform art and science activities
• Learn about life cycles
• Improve the knowledge about nature

Audiences

Primary Education

Subjects

Biology
Nature
Science
Mathematics
and Others

Skills Learned

Insects
Arachnids
Beehives
Life Cycles

Vision of the project

Insects have a great potential to attract students to science. The project tends to improve the knowledge of students about nature, biology, math, and others issues.
The teacher does not need to perform all activities. Let your creativity flow.
I suggest team work in small groups of student's and in each table a box with the 3-D printed objects. Students should communicate their own ideas in group and each group to the whole class.

Some Relevant Information about Insects and their Relatives

Insects shall be the group of living beings with greater diversity. They appear in the earth about 360 million years ago.
Scientists classify the insects and their relatives in a group they called Arthropoda. The name “arthropod” comes from two Greek words, arthros, “jointed,” and podes, “feet.” All arthropods have jointed appendages, segmented body plan, exoskeleton composed of chitin, paired jointed appendages on variable number of segments. Scientists classify insects and their relatives into categories based on similar characteristics.
The arthropod group can be divided in other groups called: Insecta (include insects), Crustacea (crabs, lobsters, shrimp, etc.), Diplopoda (millipedes, etc.), Chilopoda (centipedes,…) and Arachnida ( spiders, scorpions , ticks , etc. ) .
There are other important characteristics in the animal division by these groups,
Crustacea – Crustaceans includes lobsters, crabs, crayfish, shrimp and others.
The body of a crustacean is composed of segments. Each somite, or body segment can bear a pair of appendages:
• The cephalon or head (Two pairs of antennae, the mandibles and maxillae)
• The thorax segments bear legs, which may be specialised as pereiopods (walking legs) and maxillipeds (feeding legs)
• And the pleon or abdomen bears pleopods and ends in a telson, which bears the anus, and is often flanked by uropods to form a tail fan.
Arachnida – They have eight legs although the front legs in some species has converted to a sensory function while in other species, different appendages can grow large to take the appearance of extra pairs of legs. They have two body regions (cephalothorax and abdomen). They have chelicerae and pedipalps.
Chilopoda - Centipedes are elongate and flattened. They have a segmented body and a pair of legs per body segment.
Diplopoda - Millipedes are usually cylindrical (sometimes slightly flattened). Except for the first three trunk segments, each segment has two pairs of short legs.
Insecta – The group Insecta, which belongs insects, are Arthropoda that have three pairs of legs. The segmented body of these animals is divided into three regions: head, thorax, and abdomen. They have two antennae and usually wings. They have compound eyes which contains several thousand of lenses.
If you note, the other Arthropoda groups have more than three pairs of legs and only one or two body regions, and they never have wings.

Activity 1 - What makes an insect... an insect?

Activity objective:
Student's should discover the characteristic of the insects and how they are different from spiders.
Materials/Resources:
Fruits and vegetables
3-D printed objects (dragon fly, ant, ladybug, Butterfly, caterpillar, ant, spider, other insect) in a box.
Books/Sites with insect information for students discover the characteristics of insects and their relatives (like spiders and scorpions).
Activity Steps

  1. Divide the students in groups of four
  2. Place in each table a box with 3-D printed objects and a variety of fruits and vegetables
  3. Allow the students to explore the 3-D printed material.
  4. Encourage them to builds their own insect
  5. Ask the class about insects and write on board what they're thinking
  6. Ask questions that will lead them to think without giving the correct answers. Allow students can get the answer by themselves
  7. Allow students to discover more information about the bugs in the books and make new brainstorming.
  8. Allow students to communicate and give their explanations about what their discover in the books about insects.
  9. Use the last 15 minutes of the class to explain some scientific content.
    Additional notes: It’s important to understand what kind of PLA can be used with food. Wash the vegetables, the fruit and the 3-D Objects after you give them to the children. They will stick the objects in the food, so it’s important that the objects are clean. Don’t use the same pla you use in playdough in food (fruit’s or cake).
    If you use the spider in this activity don’t use the scorpion. You will need them for the next activity.
Activity 2 - Where is the Intruder? - Treasure Hunt in the Garden

Activity objective:
Understand if students are able to identify what is an insect and explain why the scorpion is not an insect.

Materials/Resources:
Fruits and vegetables
3-D printed objects (dragon fly, ant, ladybug, Butterfly, caterpillar, ant, scorpion, other insect) in box.
Playdough
1 garden treasure insect map (facultative)
Scientist notebook
investigation magnifying glasses for kids

Preparation:
Ask a friend to build the scorpion and place them in the garden.
No student should know the scorpion is in the garden. Another possibility is the teacher place all the insects and the intruder in the garden.

Activity Steps:

  1. Allow students build the insects with playdough.
  2. Divide the class in two groups.
  3. Tell them they are play the role of an entomologist. One of the groups will hide the insects in the garden. The other will find where the insects are. They don't know but somebody will put a scorpion in the garden.
  4. Allow the other group with the scientist notebook search the insects and write what are the characteristics of the insects.
  5. After that they change what they were doing.
  6. Finalize the activity asking about the insects they found in the garden until they speak about the intruder.
  7. Go to the garden with the glasses see the real bugs. Kids will work in a team and they can perform other activities in the garden.
Activity 3 - There's a bug in my cupcake?

Activity Objective
Scientific kitchen session about bugs, relatives and their mysteries can be used to students learn more about them.

Materials/Resources
Ask your student's what they will need
Microwave
Cupcake
Other ingredients

Activity Steps

  1. Divide the students in groups
    Students must investigate a bug or similar
  2. Students will be invited to investigate how they can cook a simple bug cupcake in the microwave.
  3. After they decide the type of recipe they what they perform the recipe and attach the parts of the bug they need (3-D printer objects) to the cake

It's important do not use in this session the same models you used in the garden.
It’s important try to understand what kind of PLA can be used with food.

Try this kind of thing:
http://www.craftsy.com/blog/2013/08/how-to-make-cake-in-a-mug-in-the-microwave/

Activity 4 - Bees know math?

Activity Objective:
Who lives in the beehive? Bee knows math?
Bees are social. They live in the hive in highly organized society.
They have common purposes of survival. In this activity students have the opportunity to explore and build with hexagons pieces and perceive the role of the queen bee, the drone and the worker. The choice of hexagonal shape of honeycomb is optimal for bees. Bees can maximize the number of alveoli minimizing the spent wax.

Materials/Resources
20/40 hexagon
Queen Bee
Drone
Worker bee

Activity Steps

  1. Present the queen, the drone and the worker bee to kids
  2. Allow students accomplish mini investigations on this type of issues
  3. It’s important they see movies or explore books before the teacher give them the scientific explanation
    The students can find interesting answers in the following websites:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QEzlsjAqADA
    http://climatekids.nasa.gov/bees/
  4. In this activity you also can use the life cycle of the bee
Activity 5 - Life Cycles of the Bee, Ant and Butterfly

Activity Objective
Understand that insects and other's animals have a life cycle. They born, develop into an adult, reproduce and die.
Observe the Life Cycle of the bee, ant and butterfly.

Materials/Resources
Life cycles of bee, ant and butterfly
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ocWgSgMGxOc

Activity Steps

  1. Place the objects of the life cycle of the three insects in a box
  2. Explain student's what is a life cycle and try them separate de pieces in the three life cycle
  3. Allow they see some films about the issues like thid one
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ocWgSgMGxOc
  4. Allow they explain the insect’s life cycle.

Other resources:
Ants: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vG-QZOTc5_Q
Life cycle about butterflies:
http://www.magicoflife.org/Life_Cycles.pdf
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aNoqN-IX5qs
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K0GP1zZ7qvs
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qO37yoTi9es

Activity 6 - Art and Science - Making My Imaginary Insect/Bugs creativity

Activity Objective:
It's time to allow students to use their creativity and imagination to build a new insect invented by them. All the combinations between art and science are possible.

Materials/Resources
Tissues, journals, 3-D Print insects, playdough et al.

Activity Steps

  1. Give the materials to kids
  2. Let them work

Note: If they want they can make a new insect with a dragon wings, a dinosaur body and a scorpion stinger

Duration

Time for each activity: 1 hour/ 1 hour and 30 minutes
(It’s depend of the interest of the student's)

Preparation

The teacher need to print the stl files and have the materials needed for the activities.
Tissues, newspapers, 3-D Print insects, playdough et al.
Laptop to see the suggested films or others they need.
Insect's Books
Children's insect magnifying glasses
Microwave
Cupcake
Other ingredients.

References

I place here not references for teacher's use because I don´t have but the references I used to build this project:
Bibliography:
http://www.iflscience.com/physics/why-do-honey-bees-make-hexagonal-honeycomb/
https://ncmns.wordpress.com/2013/06/07/what-butterflies-have-in-common-with-straws/
http://nautil.us/issue/35/boundaries/why-nature-prefers-hexagons
http://www.enchantedlearning.com/subjects/arachnids/scorpion/Scorpionprintout.shtml

Rubric & Assessment

Students should explore the Tinkercad or others 3-D design software’s. There are many more activities and 3-D objects that can be designed in the future able to engage the students on science.

Attention:
The implementation of this project should be performed only in appropriate settings and with appropriate parental, a teacher, a adult or any other supervisioner… not all Project Ideas are appropriate for all individuals or in all circumstances.
Each individual must follow safety precautions of all the materials used in the activities they realize.

Improving This Project

I started this project for Thingiverse recently. I could not finish all the files that I presented in this project since I don’t have enough time to optimize all.
For this motive I only place here the files I finished.
When printing the created files I had to make many changes.
All files least hexagon must be printed supported.

title: The Eric dice (my tutor asked me how to create this)

description.text:
Rare video footage (me talking): https://youtu.be/1mI22z_K95I?list=PLq3IPb96cA9Gn87ttM6nZs4Ya1UZxqqSH

It has become a playlist (right click - open in new tab) See the 2nd and 3rd video on how to create a tetraeder. I kind of skipped that whole step because I thought it to be easy.

This thing I just created, because my explanation on how to do it was "less" understood. After creating is I must say... I now understand why. In your head you can create a thing like this easily, but behind the computer you realize how many conditions you use to place a plane or line.

So for the people amoungh us in the autism spectrum, an interesting brain-fart story:

  1. Start with a tetraeder (in your head)
  2. On all 4 faces connect the mid-points of the edges so you devide every face in 4 equal triangles.
  3. Use the triangles to visualize the octaeder
  4. For all four faces of the octaeder that has a pointy thingy of the tetraeder normal to it's face.... PLACE a workplane on it. Yest on it, because the body doesn't exist. You only use the references (lines)

  5. Now we have the planes (4 total) we can create a mysterious looking octaeder. In this solid I used 100 units. This it the distance between the 1/2 height of two cones. I made the cones longer. From the point of the real tetraeder 8 units inward and later I added 8 units outward. The radius of the cones are 6 units.

  6. For people still with me.... I like to get to know you :-) Mailing me will be peanuts for you ;-)

  7. after creating all the workplanes you can now create new workplanes parallel to the octaeder and about 5 units distance towards the vertex of the original tetraeder.

  8. Concratulations you created a misterious octaeder with a bit of magic.

  9. On all opposite faces of the tetraeder create mid-points in the faces. No need to tell you will need to draw lines...

  10. create helplines to "save" the position of all the tetraeder end points, before you cut everything away from these second workplanes.

  11. cut all pointy thingies from the tetraeder.

  12. create the correct planes (4) to sketch the profiles of the cones on.

  13. Use the vertex and the created mid point of the face, to create an axis

  14. Create the 4 cones. Revolve / profile / axis you get the idea.

  15. Almost there... do a boundary Boss / Base with the triangles and the circles. Tangency to both faces.

I didn't tweak anything, because I just answered a question to my GURU but the thing is that you will have to find an acceptable thingy between the round problem and the curve problem.

If you understand this problem, you know that solving this another way will take some effort. the boundary will have to be done in 2 steps... Anyone willing to please send me the results...

Greetinx,
1010011011

The Eric Dice

After years living on welfare finally got a job as a Wizard (guy who can do anything) minimum wages / 0 hours to begin with. Programming / 3D designing / automation of a whole administrative process flow...

Only better boss I can imagine is Maggie Muurmans (keep up the good work).

So long story short told my teacher (I'm 43 years old) and he asked me how to solve a question a costumer had... this Dice, but now looking at it I can imagine it can puncture a tire !!!!
